pullRequest.body:
Defines operads (`Operad`), symmetric operads (`SymmOperad`), and clones (`Clone`). There is a proof that all clones have a natural operad structure. And there is a file, `Instances.lean`, that gives several most important examples of Clones. In particular, it has all of the clones (in an appropriately general form) that occur in [Post's Lattice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post%27s_lattice), and later proving the completeness of Post's Lattice is why I'm making this PR.

---

- [x] depends on: #20133 [basics and notations]
- [x] depends on: #20134 [permutations]
- [x] depends on: #20138 [operad]
- [x] depends on: #20141 [clone]

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2afd10a5d4](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20051/commits/2afd10a5d47a94d3ca60a7dff93f6b0bf377a2a5)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Clone.Notation` (new file)|53|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Clone.Basic` (new file)|442|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Clone.Instances` (new file)|847|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ClonalProperty`
`+ Clone`
`+ Commute_with_Ï†_Clone`
`+ Conjunctive_Clone`
`+ Disjunctive_Clone`
`+ EssentiallyUnary_Clone`
`+ Func_Clone`
`+ Function.CommutesWithEndo`
`+ Function.Conjunctive`
`+ Function.Disjunctive`
`+ Function.EssentiallyUnary`
`+ Function.IsAffineMap`
`+ Function.IsMultiargAffine`
`+ IsMultiargAffine_Clone`
`+ IsMultiargAffine_iff_IsAffineMap`
`+ Monotone_Clone`
`+ OneGradedOne`
`+ OneGradedOne_toOne`
`+ ProjectableProperty`
`+ Superposable`
`+ SuperposableProperty`
`+ and_ClonalProperty`
`+ clonal_CommutesWithEndo`
`+ clonal_Conjunctive`
`+ clonal_Disjunctive`
`+ clonal_EssentiallyUnary`
`+ clonal_IsAffineMap`
`+ clonal_IsMultiargAffine`
`+ clonal_Monotone`
`+ clonal_kWisePropPreserving`
`+ cloneCompose`
`+ cloneCompose_assoc`
`+ cloneCompose_id`
`+ cloneCompse_comm`
`+ clonePadTo`
`+ clonePadTo_zero`
`+ clone_AffineMap`
`+ clone_ClonalProperty`
`+ clone_id_left`
`+ clone_proj_left`
`+ clone_proj_right`
`+ conjunctive_min`
`+ disjunctive_max`
`+ function_superpose`
`+ hAdd`
`+ kWisePropPreserving`
`+ kWisePropPreserving_Clone`
`+ sigma_fst`
`+ sigma_snd`
`+ superpose`
`+ superpose_fst`
`+ superpose_snd`
`+ val_hAdd`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Operad is currently defined in terms of composing just two functions (and identities in all other slots). It would be good to add the "fill all slots" notion of composition instead, see e.g. the definition on Wikipedia: With an appropriate alternate constructor for `Operad` in terms of this other definition.

Could you please split this into 5 PRs? One for each new file?
And have all of them refer back to this one, so that the context is clear.

> Marking as draft at the moment while there are some sorries, but wanting this PR up hoping for some preliminary comments

Also, it seems that it is time to remove this disclaimer from the PR commit message. :grinning:

> Could you please split this into 5 PRs? One for each new file? And have all of them refer back to this one, so that the context is clear.

Alright, I split off four PRs for other files. This leaves just `Instances.lean`, which is the unique leaf-file in this PR. That could just be this PR, if that makes sense, since it's already dependent on the other four. Or should make its own dedicated PR?
Thanks! And yes, the final file can just stay in this PR.

For either your delectation or horror, I couldn't resist:

```
import Mathlib

structure LList (Î± : Type _) where
  Î¹ : Type
  [finEnum : FinEnum Î¹]
  f : Î¹ â†’ Î±

attribute [instance] LList.finEnum

namespace LList

@[simps]
def map {Î± Î²} (L : LList Î±) (f : Î± â†’ Î²) : LList Î² := { L with f := fun i => f (L.f i) }

def toList {Î±} (L : LList Î±) : List Î± := (FinEnum.toList L.Î¹).map L.f

@[simps]
def flatten {Î±} (L : LList (LList Î±)) : LList Î± :=
  { Î¹ := Î£ i : L.Î¹, (L.f i).Î¹
    f := fun âŸ¨i, i'âŸ© => (L.f i).f i' }

structure Hom {Î±} (L L' : LList Î±) where
  toFun : L.Î¹ â†’ L'.Î¹
  w : âˆ€ i, L'.f (toFun i) = L.f i := by aesop_cat

attribute [simp] Hom.w

end LList

instance : CoeSort (LList Type) Type where
  coe L := (i : L.Î¹) â†’ L.f i

open CategoryTheory

instance {Î±} : Category (LList Î± Ã— Î±) where
  Hom x y := LList.Hom x.1 y.1
  id x := âŸ¨fun i => i, fun i => rflâŸ©
  comp f g := { toFun := fun i => g.toFun (f.toFun i) }

structure ColoredOperad {Î±} (A : LList Î± Ã— Î± â¥¤ Type) where
  compose (L : LList (LList Î± Ã— Î±)) (c : Î±) : 
    L.map A.obj â†’ A.obj (L.map (Â·.2), c) â†’ A.obj ((L.map (Â·.1)).flatten, c)
  assoc {L : LList (LList (LList Î± Ã— Î±) Ã— Î±)} {c : Î±}
      (xs : (L.map (Â·.1)).flatten.map A.obj)
      (ys : L.map fun l => A.obj (l.1.map (Â·.2), l.2))
      (z : A.obj (L.map (Â·.2), c)) : 
    compose (L.map fun l => (l.1.map (Â·.1) |>.flatten, l.2)) c 
        (fun i => compose (L.f i).1 (L.f i).2 (fun j => xs âŸ¨i, jâŸ©) (ys i)) z = 
      A.map { toFun := fun i => by obtain âŸ¨âŸ¨i, jâŸ©, kâŸ© := i; exact âŸ¨i, âŸ¨j, kâŸ©âŸ© }
        (compose (L.map (Â·.1) |>.flatten) c 
          xs (compose (L.map fun l => (l.1.map (Â·.2), l.2)) c ys z))
```
Oh, that's not right, I intended for the homs to all be bijections. I think it would not be say hard to patch.

That's a nice definition of colored operads! And I think my main takeaway at this point is that I'm too much of a non-expert to be adding operads to Mathlib :) and it would be better left to someone else. Really I just wanted to get Clone's in, and (in my limited scope of knowledge and experience) clones extend operads, so I wanted to have those in there first (in the same way that, say, rings extend goups, so you want a definition of group first). Of course, the actual practical definition of Clone doesn't `extend Operad` because that would be very cumbersome and impractical to use.

At this point I'm thinking that I should just separate out the Clone part of this PR and just PR that, and leave someone else with more category theory background to define (colored, non-colored, symmetric...) operads.
That sounds like a good idea. I've heard several people interested in Post's theorem, so if we can get the ball rolling in  that directionw ithout get tangled up in operads that might nice.

I've been slowly working my way through this series of PRs, and I think I've reached the same conclusion. I would like to see the definition of operads be quite a bit more battle tested: can we define the usual suspects, like the associative operad, the little intervals operad, and then some coloured operads. How do we make things work in an enriched setting? Etc...

I don't know anything about clones. But if they admit a definition that doesn't use operads, I would go with that for now. We can always refactor later.

If you agree, then I suggest you go ahead with that refactor, and let's close the other PRs for now, with a short sentence about the conclusion we reached.

I should also add that I want to thank you for taking a stab at this material! I think operads will be a challenge to get working in the right generality, and you have provided an initial datapoint about how it could be done.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20133~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20134~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20138~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20141~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Alright, I think I did an alright refactor. It's back in one PR now, but it's also much shorter, but let me know if I should split it. I tried to generalize the definition of `Clone` beyond Nat/Fin like I had it before, but the "interesting" stuff is all still specialized to that case.

There's no operads of course, but I did keep the `cloneCompose` operation for clones -- the operation that turns them into an operad -- and its two accompanying basic proofs. You know, for eventually. :)

Im actually very interested in seeing the operads continued, and haven't looked through the details of the PRs (nor do I know enough about operads myself ðŸ¤· ) to judge whats quality enough to be in mathlib4). To me, it seemed @kim-em 's fast and dirty `ColoredOperad` was a contribution worth of an initial PR, let alone all the work done here already prior to focusing on just clones.
 
Am curious if we should make a feature request / raise an issue to implement operads in the category theory part of mathlib4 referencing this PR?
Generally feature requests/issue for new material in Mathlib isn't really necessary. Just make the PR. :-) Planning discussions ahead of time on Zulip of course can be helpful.
This is a very ugly long proof and I would very much like to see it cleaned up. I will try, later, I guess.
This file should be renamed `Defs`.
(and I guess `Basic` needs renaming too if that is even more basic that this file!)
I'm a bit unconvinced these two classes even belong in the same file.

I'm not sure that it would be harder: you're currently doing a lot of suffering with `PermFinPadAt` and friends.

I'm also a bit worried that this approach is harder to generalize to the coloured case (where at least in my experience all the interesting examples lie?). But I guess we have to get started.

I think the material in Operad/Perm could be made a lot nicer.

pullRequest.title: feat: operads and clones
